9. Eternal Life:
* John 3:16 (For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.)
* John 5:24 (Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever hears my word and believes him who sent me has eternal life. He does not come into judgment, but has passed from death to life.)
* John 6:54 (Whoever feeds on my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up on the last day.)
10. Manna:
* Exodus 16:15 (And when the Israelites saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, “It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat.")
* Revelation 2:17 (He who has an ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the churches. To the one who conquers, I will give some of the hidden manna. And I will give him a white stone, with a new name written on the stone that no one knows except the one who receives it.)
* John 6:31-32 (Our ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness; as it is written, ‘He gave them bread from heaven to eat.’ Jesus then said to them, “Truly, truly, I say to you, it was not Moses who gave you the bread from heaven, but my Father gives you the true bread from heaven.")

Note that these are just examples and there are many more verses that can be used to illustrate these concepts in the Bible.
how is the manna compared to Jesus? 3 references

1. John 6:48-51 (I am the bread of life. Your ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness, yet they died. But here is the bread that comes down from heaven, which anyone may eat and not die. I am the living bread that came down from heaven. Whoever eats this bread will live forever. This bread is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.”)
2. John 6:31-33 (Our ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness; as it is written, ‘He gave them bread from heaven to eat.’ Jesus said to them, “Very truly I tell you, it is not Moses who has given you the bread from heaven, but it is my Father who gives you the true bread from heaven. For the bread of God is the bread that comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.”)
3. Hebrews 9:4 (which had the golden altar of incense and the gold-covered ark of the covenant. This ark contained the gold jar of manna, Aaron’s staff that had budded, and the stone tablets of the covenant.)

These references show that Jesus is being compared to the manna that the Israelites ate in the wilderness, as the bread of life. He is the true bread from heaven that gives life to the world. The manna was a temporary provision for the Israelites while they were in the wilderness, but Jesus is the eternal bread of life that gives eternal life to those who believe in Him.
expanding on the "Counterfeit-level" dimension what scripture references can be derived from these points?

The "Counterfeit-level" dimension refers to the ways in which Satan can counterfeit or mislead God's people through scripture. Here are some examples of scripture references that relate to this dimension:

1. 2 Corinthians 11:13-15 (For such men are false apostles, deceitful workmen, disguising themselves as apostles of Christ. And no wonder, for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light. So it is no surprise if his servants, also, disguise themselves as servants of righteousness. Their end will correspond to their deeds.)
2. Matthew 7:15 (Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves.)
3. 1 John 4:1 (Beloved, do not believe every spirit, but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, for many false prophets have gone out into the world.)
4. 2 Peter 2:1-3 (But there were also false prophets among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you. They will secretly introduce destructive heresies, even denying the sovereign Lord who bought them—bringing swift destruction on themselves. Many will follow their depraved conduct and will bring the way of truth into disrepute. In their greed these teachers will exploit you with fabricated stories.)
5. Galatians 1:6-9 (I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you by the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel—which is really no gospel at all. Evidently some people are throwing you into confusion and are trying to pervert the gospel of Christ. But even if we or an angel from heaven should preach a gospel other than the one we preached to you, let them be under God’s curse!)

These references point out that Satan uses false prophets and false teachers to lead people astray and deceive them. The Bible encourages us to be vigilant and test the spirits, to make sure that we are not being led astray by counterfeit teachings.
how many counterfeits Christ are mentioned in the new testament

There are several instances in the New Testament where counterfeit Christs are mentioned. Some examples include:

1. Matthew 24:23-25 (Then if any man shall say unto you, Lo, here is Christ, or there; believe it not. For there shall arise false Christs, and false prophets, and shall shew great signs and wonders; insomuch that, if it were possible, they shall deceive the very elect. Behold, I have told you before.)
2. Mark 13:21-22 (And then if any man shall say to you, Lo, here is Christ; or, lo, he is there; believe him not: For false Christs and false prophets shall rise, and shall shew signs and wonders, to seduce, if it were possible, even the elect.)
3. 2 Corinthians 11:4 (For if he that cometh preacheth another Jesus, whom we have not preached, or if ye receive another spirit, which ye have not received, or another gospel, which ye have not accepted, ye might well bear with him.)
4. 2 Thessalonians 2:3 (Let no man deceive you by any means: for that day shall not come, except there come a falling away first, and that man of sin be revealed, the son of perdition;)

These passages indicate that there will be many false Christs that will arise, and that they will come in many forms, and will try to deceive the people. They will be able to perform signs and wonders, but that should not deceive the elect, and people should be careful not to follow them.
Was Judas a counterfeit and give references and parallels both in the old and new testament

Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve apostles chosen by Jesus, is often considered a counterfeit because of his betrayal of Jesus. He was one of the closest followers of Jesus, but ultimately he chose to betray Jesus for money.

In the New Testament, there are several references to Judas as a traitor and a counterfeit. For example:

1. Matthew 26:14-16 (Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests, And said unto them, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver. And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him.)
2. Matthew 27:3-5 (Then Judas, which had betrayed him, when he saw that he was condemned, repented himself, and brought again the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders, Saying, I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? see thou to that. And he cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed, and went and hanged himself.)
3. Mark 14:10-11 (And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went unto the chief priests, to betray him unto them. And when they heard it, they were glad, and promised to give him money. And he sought how he might conveniently betray him.)

In the Old Testament, there are no direct references to Judas as a counterfeit but there are some parallels that can be drawn with the figures of Ahithophel (2 Samuel 15:12-31) and Shebna (Isaiah 22:15-25) who were trusted advisors to the king but ultimately betrayed and plotted against him.

Judas is also an example of a person who was given great opportunity and privilege, but chose to betray and ultimately be a counterfeit.

Simon Magus is also considered a counterfeit of Christianity. He is first mentioned in the New Testament in the book of Acts, where he is described as a Samaritan sorcerer who was converted to Christianity by the apostles Peter and John (Acts 8:9-24). However, it is later revealed that he continued to use his powers to try and gain followers and promote himself as a great leader in the early Christian church (Acts 8:18-19).

Simon Magus is also mentioned in early Christian writings such as the "Letter of Peter to James" and the "Recognitions of Clement" where he is portrayed as a false teacher and a heretic who was rejected by the apostles.

References in the Bible to Simon Magus are limited to the book of Acts and early Christian writings, but there are some parallels that can be drawn with the figure of Balaam in the Old Testament (Numbers 22-24; 31:8; Joshua 13:22; 24:9-10; Nehemiah 13:2; 2 Peter 2:15, Jude 11) who was a prophet-for-hire, who tried to use his religious status for his own gain and to lead people astray.

Simon Magus is an example of a person who was given an opportunity to be a part of the early Christian church but instead used it to promote himself and lead people astray, showing the dangers of counterfeit Christianity.
